div.head: Southern Indiana in the Election of 1860: The Leadership and the Electorate
div.p: American presidential elections magnetically attract historians. General observations are made and opinions are offered regarding the supposed voting behavior of particular groups. All too often these conclusions are little more than a combination of guesswork and wishful thinking. Approximately three decades ago historians began to investigate group voting behavior through selected precinct analysis. The intervening years have witnessed the development and expansion of valuable research techniques.1 Numerous local, state, and national campaigns have been investigated, but the 1860 presidential race, because of its intimate connection with the national crisis, continually invites more detailed examination.2

The fragmentation of political parties complicates the study of the 1860 contest. Democrats split into northern and southern wings, and each branch's candidates appeared on the ballot in a number of states, including Indiana. The newly

organized Republican party unified most elements opposing the entrenched Democracy, but a small group perpetuated a more conservative approach to national affairs through the development of the Constitutional Union party. Thus four presidential candidates, Northern Democrat Stephen A. Douglas, Southern Democrat John C. Breckinridge, Republican Abraham Lincoln, and Constitutional Unionist John Bell, confronted the American—and the Hoosier—voter in 1860.

In southern Indiana thousands of voters went to the polling places on November 6, 1860, to cast their ballots for one of these four men. National, as well as precinct, winners and losers were well known within a few days, and fortunately some township voting records are extant.3 The groups which supported each presidential candidate in the Hoosier state, however, are not equally easily identified.

Much has already been written about this era of the state's history. The earliest investigation of Indiana Republicanism stressed its essentially conservative nature regarding the slavery issue and its continued opposition to the candidacy of William H. Seward without ever attempting to examine party membership or to determine what forces led to this streak of conservatism. Several years later Kenneth M. Stampp utilized the same theme and wrote of "Indiana's inherently conservative citizens." He characterized the Democratic loss after a generation of tight control as a "political revolution of fundamental significance," directly attributable to "accommodators" within the Republican party who attracted

An investigation of the Democratic element in the new Republican party in Indiana led Mildred Stoler to conclude that Democratic insurgents in northern Indiana contributed to the 1860 Republican victory. Stoler used election returns but made no attempt to determine the membership of the local parties or to analyze the composition of the element which switched allegiance.5

Although dealing primarily with the development of the Know Nothing group, Carl Brand also considered the election of 1860 and characterized the Constitutional Union movement as a continuation of the party mechanism of the American party of 1856. Support for this party dropped drastically between 1856 and 1860, however, and Brand assigns three fourths of the 1856 Know Nothing vote to the Republicans in 1860. Brand bases his conclusions primarily on statewide leadership patterns and a superficial analysis of county vote totals. No consideration is given the possibility that a shift in platform emphasis between the two election years might have resulted in foreign born support for the economically and politically conservative stance of the 1860 Constitutional Union group. There is a distinct possibility that some Know Nothings may have opposed only foreign born Roman Catholics, an antipathy easily shared by foreign born Protestants.6

Following the leadership of William E. Dodd in his 1911 article entitled "The Fight for the Northwest, 1860," chroniclers of Hoosier political history have credited German voters with a significant role in Lincoln's victory not only in Indiana but in the Northwest.7 Citing the fact that seven eighths of Indiana's German language newspapers had switched to the

Daily Journal on October 18, 1860, that the Republicans were "largely indebted" to the Germans for carrying their state ticket to victory in the October gubernatorial election while Stampp feels that the "swing of the German voters to Republicanism" was a significant feature of the election. A more recent account perpetuated this theory by erroneously stating that " Allen County was in the Democratic column, but other counties with a large German element went Republican." Such a comment ignores heavily German Dubois County of southern Indiana which supported Douglas over four to one against Lincoln.9

Who then did provide the leadership and support the various parties in the election of 1860 in southern Indiana? Where were the party workers born? What were their occupations? Were they rich or poor? Do these factors influence their conservatism on the political issues of the day? Statistical analysis of sample counties can help replace supposition with more definite answers. The present study examines a cross section of party workers in order to demonstrate the differences or similarities between the parties regarding social and economic considerations. These were the men who provided the political leadership in the fervent hope of influencing the local electorate.

One prerequisite for such election analysis is the availability of historical data. Essential statistical tools include a file of local newspapers which actively followed local political events, township voting returns, and a readable manu

South of Indiana's National Road, which runs east and west through the center of the state from Richmond to Terre Haute , the six widely scattered counties of Dearborn , Jefferson, Lawrence, Rush, Spencer , and Vanderburgh fulfilled these criteria.10 From the limited number of counties possessing the requirements, these six were selected for analysis because they offered geographic diversity and included a representative sampling of elements composing the 1860 southern Indiana electorate. Four counties— Dearborn , Jefferson, Spencer , and Vanderburgh —touch the vital Ohio River. In addition, Jefferson and Vanderburgh contain the important trading centers of Madison and Evansville . Rush and Lawrence counties are located in the interior, and virtually all their townships were agriculturally oriented as, indeed, were many townships of the river counties. All six had townships dominated by native born potential voters while Dearborn, Spencer , and Vanderburgh counties also included a substantia] foreign born sampling. Furthermore, Lawrence, Spencer , and Vanderburgh counties had active units of the Constitutional Union party, which most counties did not possess, and the Vanderburgh county press also provided coverage of the local campaigns of the two portions of the Democratic party. Together, these counties offer a broad spectrum from which historical conclusions may be drawn.11

div.p: The present investigation studies two groups: party workers, who comprise the local leadership corps, and voters. The category of party worker includes any adult male actively supporting a specific political party during the campaigns of 1858 and 1860. These were men sufficiently dedicated to the cause of their party to assume responsible roles such as delegates to or presiding officers of township, county, or state conventions. Local party newspapers frequently offered extensive lists of members active at such meetings. To determine the nativity, age, occupation, and wealth of the party workers, their names were also checked in the 1860 manuscript population schedules. The results provide a social and economic profile of local party leadership.12

Men of rather diverse nativities, ages, occupations, and wealth actively participated in local, state, and national campaigns. Yet in its totality party leadership displayed both frequent similarities and significant distinctions. Of all social factors nativity has often been isolated as a critical index in determining group voting behavior. Frequently southerners are automatically assumed to be Democrats, while voters of New England or Middle Atlantic origin are largely classified as Whigs and later as Republicans. Tables I and II dispel these overgeneralizations. It is initially surprising to find that a larger percentage of Republican party workers than Democratic party workers was born in the South as illustrated by Table I.14 A closer examination reveals that this occurred because the Democrats depended more heavily upon the foreign born for their leadership than did the Republicans. When comparing only native born party workers in Table II, it is clear that both parties drew their leadership

Therefore the designation Democrat includes men who might have supported either Douglas or Breckinridge. Excluding the Hoosier born, southerners constituted fifty-four per cent of the six sample counties' native born adult males.15 Furthermore, numerous members of this southern born group previously supported the Whig party and were naturally drawn into Republican circles.

This large block of southern born Republican party workers helps to explain why southern Indiana Republicanism was often conservative, why there was little sympathy for abolitionism in the area, and why popular sovereignty frequently received Republican support.16 It is significant, however, that the slight New England influence which was available was weighted in favor of the Republicans. Table II thus most clearly demonstrates that the birthplace of native born party workers cannot be an influential factor in differentiating between Democrats and Republicans or in predicting voter behavior.

The Constitutional Union party, with only eight per cent of their participants foreign born, attracted slightly fewer immigrants than did the Republicans. Since the Constitutional Unionists were, however, the successors to the defunct nativist American party movement, even eight per cent could be considered surprisingly large.

Among native born groups the Constitutional Unionists in Indiana depended heavily upon southerners for their party workers. According to available records no New Englanders attended party councils in any sample counties. The bulk of the party's leadership was probably composed of diehard southern Whigs who refused to coalesce with what they considered a northern oriented abolitionist organization.

div.p: Age of the party worker is the second factor considered in this analysis of group voting behavior. Conservatives are often stereotyped as being older than other political groups. Table III clearly indicates that party workers for the conservative Constitutional Unionists were no older than party workers in the other parties, and the closeness of the average ages of the three groups suggests that age was not a distinction among the parties. Thus the lack of a distinctive age pattern is another indication of the similarity of southern Indiana political leadership.

div.p:
In comparison to the absence of significant age differences, a study of the occupations of party workers does present certain contrasts among the three political parties. In keeping with Indiana's rural life style during the midnine-teenth century, Table IV shows that farmers dominated Democratic and Republican councils. Skilled laborers and professionals including doctors, lawyers, ministers, and teachers—were almost equally divided between the two parties. A greater distinction appears between the major parties regarding the percentage of businessmen and common laborers adhering to the two groups.17 The Republican party, true to stereotyped opinion, contained a slightly larger percentage of businessmen, while the Democrats, equally in keeping with their historical image, drew more support from the laboring class. The occupational profile of the Constitutional Union

A biographical study of several of these comparatively unknown party workers would probably indicate that they were businessmen with strong commercial ties to the southern states who viewed continued sectional agitation as detrimental to their economic interests. In all three parties the combined farmer and businessman categories equal approximately two thirds the entire party worker group. It is the ratio between these two segments, however, that provides contrast. Farmers dominate the Republican and Democratic organizations, while within the Constitutional Union party they are only slightly more numerous than businessmen.

div.p: Occupation is an economic as well as a social factor. It not only determines an individual's daily routine, it can also be an index to his wealth. Significantly, a slightly higher percentage of richer businessmen and a smaller portion of poorer common laborers supported the Republican party. In a more definite manner Table V illustrates wealth distribution of the party worker as a fourth factor in the determination of group voting behavior.

All party workers were economically grouped into three categories: those who possessed less than $1,000, those who held between $1,001 and $10,000, and those who had over $10,001 of personal and real property combined. Table V suggests that there was a higher proportion of Democratic
party leaders in the lower economic group, while a larger percentage of Republicans were clustered on the scale's wealthier end. But more importantly, the table also indicates that a majority of both parties' workers were firmly located in the middle wealth level. The suspicion that richer men tend to be more conservative is upheld in Table V where a far greater proportion of Constitutional Unionists are enumerated among the wealthier political leaders. It thus becomes increasingly difficult to differentiate between Democrats and Republicans, for in the main they were quite well balanced socially and economically. The Constitutional Unionists provide the only sharp contrasts among the three parties.

div.p:
As revealed in Table VI, men who participated in politics were generally wealthier than the average residents of their own county. There were pronounced differences in the average wealth of residents of the six counties. Evansville 's business interests contributed to the overwhelming wealth of Vanderburgh County , while the rich, level farmland of Rush raised its average considerably above other farming regions. Dearborn , Lawrence, and Spencer were not physiographically as fortunate as Rush, and their rolling hills were not valued as highly. Jefferson County 's average suggests that Madison could not compete as a business center with Evansville , but it should also be noted that Jefferson had a much larger rural area than Vanderburgh , which would obviously lower the county average. Nevertheless, this discrepancy between counties does not detract from the fact that party workers were generally wealthier than the average voter. Republicans usually outdistanced their Democratic opponents. In the three counties where Constitutional Unionists could be identified,
members of that party rose significantly above the level of the county in terms of wealth and surpassed even the Republicans. An exception is Vanderburgh County where wealthy Evansville businessmen apparently preferred the Republican party.

div.p: Vanderburgh County also offers an interesting comparison of the internal dissention within the faction ridden Democratic organization. Southern Indiana was the home of two prominent supporters of President James Buchanan's administration, Senator Jesse D. Bright and Congressman William H. English. While seeking to lead the party faithful in the direction of John C. Breckinridge, they were continually opposed by many rank and file Democrats who frequently controlled county and local conventions and who chose to support instead the candidacy of Stephen A. Douglas.18

Both the Douglas and Breckinridge branches of the Democratic party were well organized in Vanderburgh County , and reports of their periodic meetings provide a basis for comparing party workers in the two 1860 Democratic factions. Table VII shows that the Breckinridge movement drew over half its native born party workers from the

Further distinctions are readily apparent. Table VIII clearly shows that the Douglas faction in Vanderburgh County was both more youthful and less wealthy than its administration counterpart. The average age of forty-two years for Breckinridge supporters is almost identical to the forty-one year average age of the combined Douglas and Breckinridge party workers in all six counties surveyed in Table III. Active party workers in the Douglas campaign in Vanderburgh County , with an average age of thirty-one, were generally ten years younger than most party workers. Since the Douglas group was much younger, it is not surprising that it was also considerably less wealthy. div.p: Tables I through VIII above clearly illustrate that the Republican and Democratic parties of the six sample counties in southern Indiana were dominated by leaders with a midwestern and southern ancestry. It may even safely be assumed that many young midwestern born individuals in this region in 1860 were the progeny of southern born immigrants. Thus both major parties have a strong southern orientation in their local leadership roles. The foreign born element actively working for a political group still favored the Democratic party almost three to one, while the New England element, slight as it was south of the National Road, leaned heavily toward the Republicans. Party workers for the Constitutional Union organization offer a more interesting contrast. They tended toward the South rather than the Midwest in their direct antecedents; they included no Yankee New Englanders at all; and the foreign born element is virtually as large as that enjoyed by the growing Republican party. The party workers of all three groups were basically middle aged. Farmers were more important to both Democrats and Republicans than to the Constitutional Unionists. In the latter group businessmen were almost as important as agrarians. Common laborers were more likely to be Constitutional Unionists or Democrats than Republicans. Perhaps their unskilled jobs frequently depended upon a continuation of the southern trade which they feared a Republican victory might endanger. The two main parties were manned by men of moderate wealth while those working for the Constitutional Union organization were more likely to be wealthier than their Republican or Democratic counterparts.

Within Vanderburgh County 's divided Democracy the native born Breckinridge party workers were primarily southerners; and when that group was combined with the generous support of the foreign born element, the entire faction was of an average age and wealth comparable to the general level of party workers in all groups studied in the six county sample. In stark contrast the native born Douglas men of Vanderburgh County were basically of Middle Atlantic and midwestern origins. They too enjoyed the liberal support of immigrant activitists, and the entire group was both much younger and much less wealthy than the average party worker in the six sample counties.

No matter how diligently a few individuals may work, election results are composed of more than the votes of those who actively support a political party. Party workers provided the leadership, but they did not account for all the ballots which the electorate dropped into the boxes on November 6, 1860. Investigating local party elite is thus only one step toward understanding the composition of a political party's voting strength on the grass roots level. It is not illogical to ask if the voting patterns of the electorate in the townships are similar to those of the party leadership. Or, turning the question around, does the party leadership truly reflect the voting manpower of the group which it represents ?

What determines how a man votes? Frequently such social and economic considerations as birthplace and wealth are thought to have subtle influences in shaping political attitudes toward ideological issues. Tables I, II, and V indicate that frequently the party leadership was not subject to these influences. Can the same be said of southern Indiana's electorate in 1860? Since no historical document identifies the precise vote of every individual in each township, the researcher must utilize another device in attempting to answer this question.

A mathematical tool known as coefficients of correlation helps to demonstrate a more precise relationship between two measurable variables. The method used in this study is that of Charles Spearman's rank-difference formula. All of the townships in the six sample counties were ranked according to percentage, as in the case of Table IX, from the most Democratic, Republican, and Constitutional Unionist to the least Democratic, Republican, and Constitutional Unionist as
of 1860. This list was then compared mathematically with a similar percentage ranking of adult males born in specific geographic regions. If the percentage ranking of a specific party vote and the percentage ranking of birth in a designated geographic region is identical, the coefficient of correlation would be +1.00. If the order were exactly reversed (that is, if the most Democratic township had the lowest percentage of southern born adult males, etc.), it would be -1.00. Rarely is the result ever so clearly defined, and the usual indication is that of a positive or negative tendency.20

A correlation of the 1860 township election returns with the nativities of adult males in the six sample counties indicates both parallels and discrepancies in the relationship between the leadership and the electorate. As was true of the party leadership, there is sometimes no definite relationship between birthplace and party preference. Table IX, however, suggests several significant patterns. Perhaps sensing an impending threat to their native area in the event of a Republican presidential victory, the southern born inhabitants of the six sample Indiana counties had a high positive correlation with the Democratic party in 1860, while southern birth alone was not a determining factor in generating support for either the Republican or Constitutional Union organizations. Midwesterners, in many instances probably second generation southerners, also achieved a similar positive proximity to the Democratic voting pattern. Migrants from the East, that is, from New England and the Middle Atlantic states, show a strong tendency in the direction of the Republican party.21

div.p: A comparison of Tables I and IX indicates that party workers were not as closely tied to party affiliation by birthplace as was the average voter. Thus, while it is not safe to categorize party leadership in 1860 solely on place of birth, it is not entirely inaccurate to accept the older idea that southerners did tend toward the Democratic party while Yankees leaned in the direction of the Republicans. Although a sizable group of southerners may have become leaders in the southern Indiana Republican organization, many rank and file natives of that section still retained a positive relationship with the Democratic party. Birthplace was obviously not a strong factor in determining the voting pattern of the Constitutional Unionists, nor were the immigrants perceptively motivated by their foreign birth in deciding how to cast their ballots in 1860.

As indicated earlier in this study the role of the foreign born, particularly the midwestern German element in the election of 1860, has already generated several historical investigations. Tables I and VIII show that much of the leadership of that segment of southern Indiana's population was still actively working within the Democratic party. Table IX does not pretend to settle the question as to whether there was a mass exodus of Germans from Democratic ranks in southern Indiana in 1860. It does indicate, however, that in 1860 immigrants in these six sample counties were not strongly influenced by birthplace. Rather they were apparently divided into Democrats, Republicans, or Constitutional Unionists upon ideological or economic issues such as slavery, the promise of homestead legislation, or economic dependence upon a peaceful continuance of the southern trade pattern.

Table I illustrates that a few persons of foreign birth, did actively participate in the Constitutional Union party movement. The slight positive correlation (+.20) between that organization and the percentage of immigrants living in a township in 1860 should be interpreted with caution. It does not of necessity imply that foreigners leaned toward the successor of the American party. Rather it might indicate that when immigrants were more densely concentrated, their presence generated a greater dislike for them among the rest of the population, which in turn registered a degree of adherence toward the party which in all probability contained the diehard nativist element.

div.p: Table IX illustrates a degree of positive affiliation between southern and midwestern born voters and the Democratic party as a whole. Is the same relationship apparent when the potential voter's birthplace is correlated with the actual support received by Douglas and Breckinridge in the townships of the six sample counties? Table X shows that the relationship is sustained only in regard to the candidate of the southern Democratic group. Indeed, the positive degree of adherence of southern and midwestern born voters toward Breckinridge is even more apparent. Obviously, southern birth and probable southern ancestry become dominant factors in determining how these men voted on election day. The Douglas group, on the other hand, is much less influenced by this same factor as no definite pattern emerges in a comparable degree to that of the Breckinridge support. A slight negative attitude is reflected in the relationship between Douglas and the southern-midwestern groups, those which strongly supported his opponent, and an equally slight positive tendency of migrants from the Middle Atlantic area and from abroad is visible in Table X.

div.p: If birthplace is not always the dominant factor in shaping political views, is wealth of any greater significance in providing a clue to the voting behavior of southern Indiana's electorate in 1860? Table V illustrates that wealthy party workers tended to be found more frequently in the Republican or Constitutional Union party camps than in the Democratic organization, but equally significant was the middle wealth level of the bulk of both Democratic and Republican leadership. An investigation of the average wealth of householders and the voting patterns of the townships within the six county sample underscores this finding. Table XI shows that the Republican party carried the wealthiest townships in the sample counties more readily than did the Democrats, and in the middle wealth group of $3,001-$10,000 they carried twice as many townships as did the Democrats. Only in the poorest areas did the two parties divide the townships evenly.

is found in the voting patterns of the Republican and Constitutional Union parties. The low positive correlation reinforces the findings of Tables V and VIII that wealth was perhaps at most a minor factor in determining the party affiliation of both the leadership and the electorate.

Statistical analysis of both the leadership and the electorate of southern Indiana in 1860 at the grass roots level provides a better understanding of the composition of the political parties and voter behavior. Political councils were dominated by leaders born in southern and midwestern states. Foreign born men who actively participated in political affairs worked primarily within the framework of the Democratic organization. Most party workers were either farmers or businessmen, and the laboring element was not strongly represented. Party leadership was basically provided by moderately wealthy individuals who were normally far above the average wealth of their local area. Only within the Constitutional Union party could the leadership be termed substantially wealthy.

Not only did the party workers of the Democratic group come from a predominantly southern-midwestern background, but adult males from this same region achieved a high mathematical correlation with the same party, particularly the Breckinridge faction of the Democratic group. For these men sectional orientation was probably a determining factor as they went to the polls in 1860. Although approximately one fourth of the Democratic leadership was foreign born and ten per cent came from the Middle Atlantic states, there was no significant correlation of either group with the Democratic vote in the sample counties studied.

The Republican party drew its native born party workers in almost the same proportion as did the Democrats from the southern-midwestern group, but in contrast to the Democratic party the adult males born in those sections achieved no positive correlation with the Republican organization. For that large group of southern born males who voted Republican in 1860 the motivation to support Lincoln was generated on some basis other than southern birth. While the Middle Atlantic and New England element was almost as active in the Democratic party as in the Republican, there was a much higher positive relationship of the voters of
these two groups to the Republican party than to the Democratic organization.

Thus birthplace frequently influenced the political attitudes of some voters in 1860 in the sample counties of southern Indiana. The mere fact of southern birth and the influence this had in shaping opinions on sectional and national issues apparently generated much support for the Democratic party. In the same way migrants from the East were more inclined to view issues in the same manner as did residents in their native section, and immigrants from the East favored the Lincoln ticket in 1860. At the same time the diverse origins of many party leaders clearly indicate that some individuals were not tied to strictly sectional interests which were determined solely by circumstances of their birth. Voters, too, were sometimes free of a sectional-izing influence. For example, almost half the local leadership group of the Constitutional Union party was southern born; yet, there was no correlation of that party's voting strength with votes of southern origin.

Although the Republicans may have tried hard to attract the foreign born voter in 1860, they did not succeed in generating a large immigrant leadership group in their local party units in the six sample counties. Perhaps, however, the measure of Republican success in wooing this group should not be measured by the party workers who seemingly still preferred the Democratic party, or the newspaper editors who switched to the Republican column, but rather by the fact that birthplace was apparently neutralized as a factor in determining how an immigrant voted. While the foreign born voter showed no positive correlation with the Republican party in 1860, there was, even more significantly, no positive correlation with the Democratic party in that year, although a fairly high positive correlation had existed as late as 1856.22 At least in the six county sample the immigrant did not react as a German toward a particular party but rather as a farmer or a businessman, or, as has often been conjectured, perhaps he voted on the basis of his attitude toward the institution of slavery.

div.p: This study indicates that the party leadership of the three political organizations of southern Indiana in 1860 had a strong southern and midwestern orientation. It is thus not surprising that the political expressions of meetings which they controlled should reflect that southern background and tend toward a conservative rather than a radical stance regarding abolition, states rights, and the doctrine of popular sovereignty.

Several decades ago Kenneth M. Stampp claimed that "No region was more vitally interested in the preservation of the Union …. The inhabitants of the river counties often felt a warmer friendship toward their neighbors in Kentucky than toward their fellow citizens in Indiana who dwelt north of the National Road."23 Having determined the basically similar southern-midwestern background of the party leadership of southern Indiana, as well as the lack of outstanding-differences in age and wealth, one may more readily see why the area has often been viewed as a distinctive unit. Not only did many of the southerners in the area align themselves with the Democratic party in a pattern which expressed their sectional nativity, but, of even more significance, the local Republican and Constitutional Union parties were led by a southern born elite. Little wonder that southern Indiana in this era was seen by many as a conservative southern enclave within the framework of the northern states.

div.head: Gas Buggy Revisited: A "Lost" Novel of Kokomo , Indiana
div.p: In December, 1933, the New York publishing house of Napier & Noyes issued a novel by Robert Paterson. The 337 page book, entitled Gas Buggy, attracted very little attention and was not widely reviewed. The only known reference contemporary to its publication appeared in the Literary Digest with the single comment: "An account of the origin of the automobile woven into a rather crude novel."1 No mention was made of the fact that the characters in the novel were thinly disguised real persons or that the setting was Kokomo , Indiana. In reality, however, the book develops with great faithfulness the automobile manufacturing careers of Indiana's two great pioneers in this industry, Elwood Haynes and Elmer Apperson. Yet it appears that no one in Kokomo learned of the novel's existence at the time of its publication or became aware of its close depiction of the men and events upon which the city today bases many of its claims to distinction.2

div.p: On the surface Gas Buggy purports to be a purely fanci ful account about the early days of the automobile—its inven tion and its manufacture—set in the mythical midwesterr town of Richford, Indiana. The author attempts to give romantic and dramatic appeal to the story through a ful airing of the domestic problems faced by one of the Richford automobile manufacturers. The industrialist's marriage to a young girl from a working class family is complicated by the incessant demands of the girl's relatives for jobs, favors and social advantages. This eventually leads to a divorce and the complete disruption of communications between the young woman and her importunate relations. Paterson injects an apparent aura of realism into his novel through the careful use of chronology and the occasional mention of nationally known men and events.

In fact, Gas Buggy is more realistic than fictional. Not a true novel at all, it is, rather, a close reconstruction of the history of the automobile—and some of the men who made it—in Kokomo . Although Paterson utilizes considerable poetic license in his analyses of local events and such things as personal motivations and conversations, each major industrial and social development in the book has its factual basis. As a result, Paterson's work is a curious mixture of fact and

The official motto of Kokomo , "City of Firsts," is based not only upon the automobile but also upon such things as innovations in the packaging of canned goods, the construction of lifeboats, the introduction of new alloys (also an Elwood Haynes legacy), and breakthroughs in the production of car radios. Gas Buggy begins with a brief account of the initial test run of an automobile in Indiana, considered by Paterson to be the first automobile in America. The inventor of this remarkable piece of machinery is " Tipton Howe" of "Richford, Indiana." A review of Howe's background and his relationship with the natural gas industry of Indiana follows. A number of factors contribute to the inescapable conclusion that Tipton Howe is Paterson's name for Elwood Haynes. The account of the invention itself parallels Haynes' actual experiences with the automobile. Haynes was also employed by natural gas companies for fifteen years, 1886-1901, during which time, because of the extensive travel requirements of his job, he undertook the studies and experimentations which led to his first car. Moreover, Haynes enjoyed throughout his lifetime a national reputation as the builder of "America's First Car," and Paterson gives an identical attribution to Howe.3

div.p: The initial chapter in Gas Buggy is followed by an introduction to the "McDonald brothers," Alan and Donald, and the machine shop on the near south side of Richford which they operate. In time their shop becomes the first automobile factory in the nation. Quite clearly these characters coincide with Elmer and Edgar Apperson who operated the Riverside Machine Shop in Kokomo in the 1890s. It was the Appersons to whom Haynes had turned in 1893 when he was ready to construct his vehicle, and the famous Haynes "Pioneer," a gasoline powered, one cylinder marvel now on permanent display at the Smithsonian Institution, was built in their machine shop in 1893-1894.4 Paterson narrates these developments much as they took place. He then describes a joint "Howe-McDonald" manufacturing effort, which is followed by separate "Howe" and "McDonald" companies, and, again, there is little fiction in his account. Haynes and Apperson, after their success with the "Pioneer" in 1894, formed a partnership the following year and began to produce automobiles. The firm was formally incorporated as the Haynes-Apperson Company in 1898, but this arrangement lasted only until 1901 when Elmer Apperson withdrew to form, with his brother, a rival firm.5 When the Apperson Brothers Automobile Company was organized, Haynes finally left the gas industry and took up full time work in manufacturing. Initially he operated under the original corporate name, but he changed it to the Haynes Automobile Company in 1905.6

An additional example of the close parallels which Paterson maintains in his book is found in his account of the McDonald firm, which develops a remarkable car soon in demand throughout the country. In actuality the Haynes Automobile Company closed its doors in 1925; the Apperson Brothers Automobile Company, acquired by eastern investors in 1924, failed in 1926.8 Although the specific reasons for failure differ, both companies in the last analysis were victims of the increasingly effective competition coming from Detroit , particularly from Henry Ford.

After the character introductions and the story of the first automobile in his early chapters, Paterson begins an extended account of the courtship and marriage of Alan McDonald (Elmer Apperson). Upon establishing himself in his own business, this rising young industrialist, to the astonishment of his associates, rejects a girl from a prominent family in Richford and rather abruptly marries a salesclerk, Hattie Sawyer. Their wedding is described in chapter VI, and the balance of the book concentrates on this marriage and the difficulties McDonald has with the Sawyer family. Confronted with a scheming mother-in-law, a jealous sister-in-law and her oafish husband, and a lazy and dishonest brother-in-law, McDonald decides, reluctantly, to terminate the marriage. He has been unable to persuade Hattie, his wife, to assume her proper role as wife and homemaker; consequently, after arranging for a generous financial settlement, he sues for divorce. Some years later McDonald remarries, this time a girl from Chicago , but the couple live only briefly in Richford.9

div.p: The aspects of Elmer Apperson's life and personal relationships which gave rise to these pages in Gas Buggy have not been thoroughly explored, but the superficialities, at least, are consistent with the facts. Apperson was indeed married twice, the second time to a Chicagoan, and subsequently he lived in Chicago although he maintained a home in Kokomo . No mention was made of Apperson's two marriages in the obituaries which were published upon his untimely death in 1920,10 but the fact that he was married twice is confirmed by the Kokomo city directories. The 1905 directory, for example, contains a listing for Mr. and Mrs. Elmer (and Olive) Apperson. There are separate listings for Elmer Apperson and Olive Apperson in 1915 and new listings for Mr. and Mrs. Elmer (and Catherine) Apperson and Olive Apperson in 1919.11 In real life, then, Apperson, as did McDonald in "Patersonm's novel, married shortly after establishing his own automoibile company. Subsequently divorced, be remarried late in life, but the new relationship was cut short by the early death of the automobile manufacturer.

Although such intimate personal details (and more of a similar nature) account for many pages in Gas Buggy, it is the industrial history supplied in the background that gives the book its lasting interest. In the final, seemingly hastily written chapters Paterson summarizes events much too quickly to be wholly accurate, but he does comment on the industrial development and diversification of Richford ( Kokomo ),

On the surface, of course, Paterson's story is not a gripping one. Its fascination lies in its factual basis, with perhaps the most intriguing question of all being why was it written. Was Gas Buggy intended to be factual, to retell a story which was familiar to Hoosiers for a wider audience? Was it an attempt to modify the familiar story, to alter subtly the accepted version? As a third alternative, was it written to expose some mildly scandalous personal details about Kokomo 's automobile pioneers with the names changed as a protection against lawsuits? In any event, the use of fictional names for the setting and the main figures does not conceal who and what the book is about. Paterson rarely strays from the facts concerning Kokomo when he describes Richford, its major thoroughfares, its leading residential districts, or its factory locations.14 As indicated, his major characters are closely patterned after the leading industrialists of Kokomo during the 1910s and early 1920s. Moreover, once the primary identifications have been made, it is possible to name the real life counterparts of many other characters in the book. Howe's family of four, including a daughter and a son, coincides with the Haynes family, even to the extent of a closely drawn portrait of Mrs. Bertha Haynes, "Rebecca Howe" in the novel. She is accurately described by Paterson as not being "a social aspirant. For years her sole interest outside her unpretentious home was the Montgomery Avenue Presbyterian Church. Paterson did, of course, manufacture some of his episodes and character idiosyncracies. Although Haynes' career is comparatively well known,23 the author of Gas Buggy was apparently unwilling or unable to go into the complex story of Haynes' true background and his activities with the gas company, the automobile company, and two metallurgical companies. Paterson contented himself instead with a highly oversimplified account of the inventor's life and character. He makes him a lowly bill collector for the gas company in Richford, for example, rather than the field superintendent who was in charge of many of the company's major projects. Paterson also makes Howe conform to the popular view of the inventor, developing to an extreme degree the dreamy, impractical, amateurish nature of the man. Although this is overdone and only partially applies to Haynes, it is nevertheless a useful corrective to the highly adulatory, totally uncritical interpretations of Haynes which are usually found.

In his book Paterson credits Howe with two outstanding contributions—the invention of the automobile in America and the discovery of a miraculous new alloy called "Cutalite" which provided the basis, late in life, for Howe's fortune. Similar credits, of course, are attributable to Haynes.24 The claim that Haynes invented the automobile is, of course, exaggerated. Not only did this invention, a cumulative one not the work of any single individual, occur in Europe, but the
23 The published works on Haynes are few and incomplete, but he has been the subject of countless newspaper and magazine articles and at least two graduate theses. One of the best of the former is O. D. Poster, "How Elwood Haynes Came to Build the First 'Horseless Carriage,'" Forbes Magazine, XV (March 1, 1925), 678-82; the best of the latter is Mary E. Harshbarger, " Elwood Haynes: Scientist with a Social Conscience" (Ed.D. dissertation, Department of History, Ball State University, 1965). Moreover, the Elwood Haynes Papers are now open to scholars at the Elwood Haynes Museum in Kokomo .
24 "Cutalite" is mentioned by Paterson in Gas Buggy on page 116 and passim. His comments about the alloy apply directly to Stellite, the alloy Haynes finally developed, after years of experimentation, in 1912. Haynes began producing the alloy in small quantities in that year, and soon a considerable market for it appeared. In 1920 Union Carbide Corporation paid Haynes and his two partners several million dollars for their Stellite business. Kokomo
Daily Tribune, April 19, 1920. This account reported that Haynes, Ruddell, and Patten shared a $4,000,000 payment.
Duryea brothers (J. Frank and Charles) of Massachusetts and Illinois are now properly credited with having anticipated Haynes' first car by a few months. Yet it is true that Haynes throughout his lifetime was widely recognized as being the American inventor of the automobile.25 This in itself is an interesting switch since many inventors fail to have their work recognized until after their death. Haynes, moreover, enjoyed acclaim not only for his automobile of 1893-1894 but also for his metallurgical genius which yielded two remarkable alloys—stainless steel and Stellite.

Stellite, Paterson's "Cutalite," is a nonferrous alloy of cobalt, chromium, and tungsten which possesses incredible hardness even at elevated temperatures. Extraordinarily heat, wear, and corrosion resistant, Stellite resulted from a series of experiments which Haynes made in search of a stainless cutlery metal. The alloy proved unsatisfactory, because of its hardness and the resultant difficulty in shaping it, for cutlery purposes, but Stellite became enormously significant as a tool metal (a metal to cut other metals).26 It virtually replaced high speed steel in the machine tool industry's severe service applications and, as Paterson noted, provided the basis for Haynes' wealth during the last few years of his life. The automobile, by contrast (and Paterson correctly reports this, too), brought Haynes fame but not fortune.27

div.p: It is in explaining Haynes' background and in describing the events that led to the conception of the "Pioneer" that Paterson departs markedly from reality. In the novel Howe is a gas company employee required to travel many long hours by horse drawn buggy in order to collect the gas bills. In reality Haynes managed the Kokomo gas company office for nearly ten years after he had supervised the installation of the system, and had directed, between 1890 and 1892, the construction of America's first long distance pipelines for the transmission of natural gas.28 It was in the course of this work that Haynes' extensive travel requirements caused him to give serious thought to improved overland transportation methods.

Paterson, then, is quite correct in saying, as he does in the opening line of the book, that "the discovery of natural gas in northern Indiana—back in the late eighties—was responsible for the [Haynes] invention of the automobile."29 It is only his explanation of the precise relationship between the two events that needs to be modified. Undoubtedly the same thing is true in other parts of the novel. The main developments, and often a great many of the details, are scrupulously factual, but the facts have been embroidered in some places, considerably oversimplified and compressed in others.

It is particularly interesting to note Paterson's account of the initial cooperation between Howe and the McDonald brothers, followed by their separation and eventual strong rivalry as automobile manufacturers in Richford. This rivalry was stoked by highly competitive advertising departments

As most automobile historians know, Haynes took his idea and drawings to the Appersons, proprietors of the Riverside Machine Shop. There the "Pioneer" was constructed, during the course of which some modifications were made to the original plans. The Appersons and their men were paid at a rate of forty cents an hour for their labor which, it was agreed, would be performed only during slack times in the shop. These things, as indicated, were quite generally known, and it is to be expected that Paterson would pick them up. What is surprising is the role assigned by Paterson to his character, Art Snelling. He, as did his real life counterpart, A. G. Seiberling, serves as the general manager of both automobile companies, and Paterson quite explicitly credits Snelling with developing each company into successful manufacturing concerns. The Howe company flounders under Howe's personal direction, but it revives and prospers after Snelling is induced to leave McDonald and take over the rival firm. Similarly, the McDonald company, which gets off to a disappointingly slow start, becomes an industry leader under Snelling's guidance, and its prominence continues for a few years after it reverts to McDonald's control.32 This viewpoint, presented in a bold, exaggerated form in the novel, appears to have considerable merit when applied to the Haynes and Apperson companies. Under the rather hard driving, aggressive direction of Seiberling each company was relatively prosperous and successful. When they were managed by their founders, however, the results were less pleasing. Both companies failed in the mid-1920s, but by then Seiberling had been dismissed from the Haynes company, an act which coincided with the scrapping of his plans for a small, less expensive Haynes automobile, and the Apperson company was being operated by a syndicate from New York .33

That this interpretation about the crucial role played by Seiberling was Seiberling's own is not remarkable, but it lends some support to the idea that Seiberling, who lived until 1952, was Paterson's source for many of the facts about the two automobile companies and their officers. Certainly a great deal of what appears to be "inside" information was available to the author of Gas Buggy. He evidently had access to data about company operations which have since been destroyed or which were supplied to him by company officers or employees who wanted their side of the story told. In particular, in the generally accepted account of the demise of the Haynes Automobile Company, Seiberling is the scapegoat;34
32 Gas Buggy, 167-69, 243, 314-21.
33 Huffman, "The Apperson Brothers," 202.
Paterson's version is at great variance with this. Rather, it conforms closely to Seiberling's own interpretation of the episode, written in the 1950s, and it raises the question of a similar origin for both accounts.35

Gas Buggy has many shortcomings. As a novel it is banal and unexciting and exhibits few of the techniques of successful fiction. Paterson, to quote an authority on twentieth century American literature, "knew nothing at all about writing novels."36 His characters are one dimensional and scarcely believable, and the author excessively utilizes the annoying practice of writing in incomplete sentences. As an historical account the book is unreliable in that one never knows, without the most painstaking verification, whether an event described is factual or not. Thirdly, if the book was intended in any way as an expose, it obviously failed because of its obscurity. It seems that only the Duryea family in Massachusetts recognized the novel as intimately involved, at least in part, with the life and career of Haynes, but the purpose which the Duryeas sought to have it serve was as ludicrous as many of the scenes in the book. The Duryeas cited Gas Buggy as additional evidence that the original Haynes car was faulty and that it was a laughing matter when it first appeared on the streets of Kokomo and as supportive of their claim that the Duryeas (who are scarcely mentioned in the book) should be recognized as the original builders of the automobile in America.37

div.p: There are still several unanswered questions about Gas Buggy. Paterson himself remains rather enigmatic, as do his motives for writing the book. Was he hired to do so? Did he get most of his facts and his interpretations from one source, a not disinterested one? Was it Seiberling, an Apperson relative or acquaintance, or a Duryea? On another level, why has the book not been associated with Kokomo and its citizens before?38 Was this the result of a conscious effort? The book is difficult to locate. A copy is in the Automotive History Collection of the Detroit Public Library because it was placed there by a member of the Duryea family, and the Library of Congress has a copy; but no others have been located in libraries in Indiana or elsewhere.

The book deserves better than this. For all its defects it is a factually based story which offers useful hypotheses and insights into the people and events discussed. Obviously written with access to information not available today in the published sources or known collections of manuscript material, the novel, despite its "embroidery" of various events, has value as an historical reference. In its evocation of an age and a way of life now gone and in its relation to the industrial history of Kokomo , it has considerable merit. In addition, the book contains useful references to such things as the Indiana interurban system, one "surpassed by none other in the world,"39 the elections of 1912 and 1916, the mood of the Midwest in the pre-World War I and wartime periods, and the early days of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway (the Appersons, hence the McDonalds, were in the 1911 and 1912 races); and, interspersed throughout, there are some worthwhile comments about the development of the automobile industry in the United States into the 1920s. All Hoosiers and all others interested in Indiana history, and certainly those Kokomoans concerned about the history of their locality, should know of Robert Paterson's still mysterious Gas Buggy.

div.head: Democratic Attitudes in Johnson County during the Civil War Era: A Look at the Demaree Papers
div.byline: Edited by William G. Eidson and Vincent Akers*
div.p: The Demaree family of north central Kentucky and Johnson County , Indiana, has left an absorbing legacy in a collection of more than seventy unpublished letters.1 Full of politics, religion, farming, and family news, the letters offer a valuable commentary on life in Indiana and Kentucky during the turbulent middle decades of the nineteenth century. The patriarch of the family was Samuel Demaree, a prosperous farmer in Henry County, Kentucky . Of French Hugenot and Dutch ancestry, Samuel was born in 1792, the year Kentucky became a state. His father and grandfather had moved to Kentucky in the 1780s with a large migration of Dutch families from Pennsylvania and New Jersey . Within a few years after Samuel's birth his father had moved to the "Low Dutch Tract" in Shelby and Henry counties. Here many of the Dutch families had pooled their interests in 1786 to purchase a tract of over 8,000 acres. The land was held by the Low Dutch Company until deeded to individuals in the 1830s. Samuel's farm was carved out of the portion of the tract lying in Henry County .2

list.item: * William G. Eidson is associate professor of history at Ball State University, Muncie . Vincent Akers, a C.P.A. with Price Waterhouse & Co., is a Demaree descendant with a special interest in Johnson County history.

1 The original letters are in the possession of David B. Demaree, Pleasureville, Kentucky . Transcribed copies of the letters may be seen at the Indiana Historical Society Library, Indianapolis . All pictures are from the collection of Mr. Akers.

2 Information on the early family background and "Low Dutch" connections comes primarily from family papers, grants, deeds, depositions, and memoranda in Mr. Akers' possession. Samuel Demaree's deed from the Low Dutch Company, dated September 12, 1836, is recorded in Deed Book, XVIII, 6-7 ( Henry County Courthouse, New Castle, Kentucky ).

div.p: While Henry County magistrate in the 1820s and 1830s Samuel watched seven of his younger brothers and sisters migrate to Johnson County , Indiana, where the younger Demarees and many of their Dutch relatives hoped their financial prospects would be better.3 Samuel, a slaveholder, did not follow their example. Samuel and his wife, Rachel, raised thirteen children in Kentucky , a border state becoming increasingly divided in the years just prior to the Civil War. In order of their birth the thirteen were: David (1814-1874), Henry (1816-1890), Elizabeth (1818-1907), Peter (1819-1888), Mary (1820-1908), Ann (1822-1907), Susan (1823-1882), Albert (1825-1841), Samuel (1827-1871), John (1829-1915), George (1832-1915), Joseph (1833-1858), and Cornelius (1836-1898). The letters printed below are from their fourth child, Peter, and from William T. Shuck (1824-1900), the husband of Susan, their seventh child.4

Susan and her husband moved to Johnson County , Indiana, shortly after their marriage in 1847. There they settled in the Shiloh community in Union Township where Shuck farmed and became a leader in the local Presbyterian church. His behavior, however, puzzled many of those who knew him well. Always a faithful church attender and a staunch Democrat, he nevertheless gained a reputation for being one of the most cantankerous and stubborn men in the county. One of his six children wrote of Shuck: he was "the most unreasonable, wicked man I ever saw."5

Peter Demaree, nearly five years older than Shuck, did not move to Johnson County until 1856. Like other Demarees he was a devout Presbyterian and an active Democrat. Many of his letters reflect these two interests. Following in his father's footsteps, Peter dabbled in local politics and was elected Johnson County commissioner for three years.6 Peter

Once, after Peter accused William of opening a letter which did not belong to him, Shuck angrily implied that Peter and his whole family were liars.7

All the letters printed below were written to George Whitefield Demaree, Samuel's eleventh child. While a young man George did some pioneering in Missouri ; but by 1856 he had returned to Kentucky , where he lived the remainder of his life. He was a Kentucky Democrat with strong beliefs in states rights and slavery. Outwardly he remained neutral during the Civil War, but inwardly his sympathies were with the Confederacy. George was a deeply religious, Presbyterian elder who penned many articles expressing his premillenial beliefs. His chief fame and main source of income, however, came as a beekeeper. Through numerous articles and noteworthy experiments, George became a nationally known apiarist. He was also interested in history and preserved most of the letters now found in the Demaree Collection.8

In the first letter printed below Shuck provides some insight into the crippling effects a drought can have on a farming community and observes the cooperative method for dealing with crises. div.p: The second letter, from Peter Demaree to his brother in Kentucky , reflects the concerns of a typical Indiana farmer at this time in history. Health, money, and the war are uppermost in his thoughts. The Missouri lands mentioned were inherited when Peter's father died in 1858. Samuel had been given land in Missouri for service in the War of 1812. At the same time he bought cheaply large tracts of additional Missouri land from other veterans who preferred ready cash to uncultivated soil. By this method the elder Demaree acquired thousands of acres in Missouri , which were then divided among his heirs.27 The depressed prices on sugar, coffee, and cotton remained low throughout the latter half of 1861, but the hog price of two dollars was only half what hogs had been bringing three months earlier.28

Eleven deeds were drawn up, each of which had to be signed by all of the heirs and their husbands and wives. The brothers and sisters were at that time living in Kentucky , Indiana, and Missouri , and all the deeds were sent to each state to be signed and notarized. Even after the last of the heirs in Missouri had finally signed in October of 1860, the trouble was not nearly over. William T. Shuck in a letter dated January 20, 1861 (Demaree Collection), and addressed to Samuel Demaree, Jr., who was handling the division, brought up a matter of pride which further delayed the recording of the deeds:
"I feel that you have treated us with Scorn & contempt I kno that we wil get the Same Shear the way the deeds are, but what man wants to send a deed to the recorders office to be recorded in his wife's name I do not care Ef She is the Heir of inheritence, the Supposition arises that She is a widow otherwise her husband is a worthless bankrupt & not worthy to manage his wife's affairs.
"You Say those deeds must be Recorded next Spring, Ef you wil make them as they Should be made we will have them Recorded Ef not I care but littel what becomes of them that is my feeling about it …." By the time this point was cleared up the war had made it unsafe to have the deeds recorded; thus, the recording was delayed until September 25, 1866.
31 In September, 1861, Confederate forces under General Leonidas Polk seized Columbus , and Union troops under Grant retaliated by occupying Paducah. During the reminder of the year Union troops moved into Louisville and Covington while Confederates advanced to Bowling Green and the Cumberland. Though no major battles occurred in Kentucky during 1861, the situation was tense as counties, cities, and even families divided their loyalties. div.p: Shuck wrote the next letter only five weeks after Peter penned the one above. Again there is complaint about low farm prices. Actually from 1859 to the outbreak of the war in 1861 farm prices had risen steadily in Indiana. Then prices fell and remained low for several months. Recovery came in 1862, and prices continued to rise for the remainder of the war. Shuck mentions selling corn for twenty-five cents per bushel. This is as low as the price dropped. By 1864 corn was selling for ninety-five cents per bushel, the highest figure reached during the war.32

The Wild Cat Battle was not as impressive a Union victory as the letter indicates. Northern troops pursued a Confederate force from Perryville, Kentucky , toward the Cumberland Gap . The southerners, who were heading for Tennessee , tried to slow the Yankee pursuit by blocking roads with fallen trees. The battle occurred in October, 1861, near London, Kentucky , when some northern soldiers overran a small detachment of Confederates engaged in delaying tactics. A few hundred men on each side participated in the skirmish with total casualties amounting to less than seventy-five.33

div.p: In the first paragraph of the next letter Peter mentions money received from his brother George. Since Shuck and Henry Demaree also received money about the same time, Peter is undoubtedly referring to an inheritance from his father's estate.

The substitutes mentioned in paragraph two were men who, for a substantial sum of money, agreed to take a draftee's place in military service. Four hundred dollars was not an excessive amount, however, for in some sections of the North substitutes were paid more than a thousand dollars.40 Then,
39 Consolation was a railroad depot and post office in northeastern
Shelby County, Kentucky , near where George W. Demaree was living.
40 The original purpose of substitution was to allow those in critical jobs to aid the war effort by remaining at home while another took their place in the service, but in reality anyone who had the resources and the desire could furnish a substitute without reference to the importance of his position. At the time Peter wrote this letter draft boards could exempt a man the whole term for which he was drafted if the draftee would provide a substitute who was not eligible for the draft. If the substitute was eligible for the draft, then the draftee's name was again placed on the rolls for future calls. Eugene Converse Murdock, Patriotism Limited, 1862-1865 ( Kent, Ohio , 1967), 9-10, 31-32; Jack Franklin Leach, Conscription in the United, States: Historical Background (Rutland, Vt., 1952), 256, 396-97; U.S., Congressional Globe, 38 Cong., 1 Sess., Appendix, 140-42, 257.
as now, no one wanted to be drafted, especially one who totally opposed the war as did many in Union Township and Johnson County as a whole.41 Townships did all possible to raise their quotas without resorting to the draft. It is doubtful that the citizens of Union Township raised subscriptions so much out of patriotic enthusiasm as out of the desire to avoid sending their young men to a war they did not favor. Also, by raising their quota through subscription, the citizens avoided the stigma of cowardice that was sometimes attached to anyone who was drafted. That some of the townships had to draft is not difficult to explain. This was the third time in six months that the national government had called for additional troops. Johnson County 's quota for these three calls was 920.42

Most of the Johnson County residents were unhappy with the Lincoln administration. Peter wrote that he intended to vote for George B. McClellan; so did most of his neighbors. Johnson County was so thoroughly Democratic that it voted for the Democratic presidential candidate in every election from 1824 to 1920. In 1864 the county cast 1,713 votes for McClellan and 1,532 for Lincoln. The state, however, gave Lincoln fifty-four per cent of its vote.43

Brother Samuel, referred to in the last paragraph of this letter, joined the Confederate army in 1863 rather than be drafted by the Union in Kentucky . He rode with John Morgan's raiders in their romp through Indiana and Ohio but was eventually wounded and captured. He spent several months in the prison hospital at Camp Chase, Columbus, Ohio , before Henry obtained his release. He lived with Henry's family in Johnson County for a year before returning to Kentucky .44

div.p: The next letter from Shuck is interesting for the observations he makes about the end of the war, Lincoln's assassination, and John Wilkes Booth. The letter also demonstrates that to a farmer national events were important, but so were the spring rains and the price of land.

Shuck's letter exemplifies the phonetic spelling of that era. A clear distinction was not made between the "e" and "i" sounds in many words. Thus Shuck wrote "sence," "ef," distroyed," and "distruction." Other words, while not conforming to current spelling practices, are easily recognized and make for delightful reading. Some examples are: "broak," "deth," "helth," "littel," "reddy," "rool," and "wo."

The last letter from Peter Demaree is in many ways the most fascinating of the six printed here. The letter and the newspaper article following it picture in a few words the attitude of the average Hoosier toward blacks in 1867. One historian who has studied attitudes toward blacks during the Civil War wrote that of all the midwestern states Indiana was the most conservative by far. The racial situation did change somewhat after the war when the Indiana Supreme Court declared null and void the provisions of the Indiana Constitution which excluded blacks from entering the state and when the state legislature modified the law which excluded blacks from testifying in court. Nevertheless, many Indiana communities strongly discouraged blacks from settling in their midst, and it continued to be unlawful for black children to

The six letters printed here reveal an interesting change in the attitudes of two northern Democrats during the era of the Civil War. In the first letter Shuck is nearly ecstatic as he brags that the Democrats have outsmarted the Republicans in the 1856 elections. The war, however, changed that attitude abruptly. No expression of triumph, no sense of bragging are seen in the letters of the 1860s. Both Peter and Shuck cry out against the futility of the war in 1861. By 1864 Peter exhibits a feeling of political frustration and hopelessness. Instead of lauding the Democrats he laments that the Republicans have probably won again in Indiana and that no one the Democrats nominate can defeat Lincoln.

Shuck and Peter were never stalwart supporters of the war or of Lincoln's administration. It is not surprising then to find in Shuck's 1865 letter no attitude of vindictiveness. No "bloody-shirt" phrases come from his pen. Instead the former Kentuckian expresses fear and concern for the fate of defeated southerners. He had not agreed with their secessionist stand, and he had not supported them in the conflict that followed; but he fears that their punishment will be greater than their crime. And 1867 finds Peter, a Hoosier who had signed slave deeds less than ten years earlier,62 in the midst of postwar difficulties relating to social equality of the blacks. Such difficulties were not unusual for residents of Indiana in the post-Civil War era, nor have they been completely resolved today.

div.p:
To ALL TO WHOM THESE PRESENTS MAY COME, GREETING:
WHEREAS, The Indiana General Assembly in 1967 approved a resolution requesting "that the month of April annually be declared Hoosier History and Heritage Month by formal proclamation of the Governor," and
WHEREAS, the United States is beginning the Bicentennial Era of its birth as a nation; and
WHEREAS, the Old Northwest from which the State of Indiana was carved became the proving ground for establishing and developing a territorial policy by which new states were admitted into an expanding Union; and
WHEREAS, the congressional Enabling Act approved in April of 1816 resulted in the formation of a state constitution at Corydon and Indiana's admission to the Union on December 11, 1816:
NOW, THEREFORE, I, Otis R. Bowen, Governor of the State of Indiana, do hereby proclaim the month of April, 1974, as
HOOSIER HISTORY AND HERITAGE MONTH
and recommend that especially during the month of April Hoosiers visit Indiana's historic sites and places; that lectures, exhibits, tours, and other programs which increase understanding of and appreciation for our state and national heritage be emphasized; and that Indiana citizens generally cooperate in developing projects and programs appropriate for a commemoration of our state and national origins.

div.head: Awards of Merit and Certificates of Commendation from American Association for State and Local History
div.p: All nominations must be made on the "Awards Nomination Form" and postmarked by not later than May 15, 1974. Each nominator must include a supporting letter which is explicit in indicating why the award or certificate seems merited. Each nominator is also responsible for making certain that at least two or three other persons send similar statements directly to the state chairman. Finally, each nominator should send relevant supporting material such as pamphlets, newspaper clippings, programs, scripts, and books. The views and evaluations of various persons will be considered regarding each nomination.

list.item: 1. Certificate of Commendation. The Certificate of Commendation is given for outstanding achievement by an individual or an organization in the field of state, provincial, and local history, but with that achievement judged in the light of local limiting circumstances rather than on a basis of overall excellence in the United States and Canada as a whole. This is an award of encouragement and commendation to a person or group which by great effort has accomplished something that is really outstanding within its own area. The certificate is a pat on the back and says to the individual or organization that receives it: "We think you are doing a wonderful job in your area, and we want to recognize you for it."

2. The Award of Merit. This was the original award of the American Association for State and Local History and is still the backbone of its competition. It is given for excellence of accomplishment or program in the field of state, provincial, and local history and is in no way judged relative to local limiting circumstances. The giving of the Award of Merit is the same as saying to everyone: "This is public acknowledgement by the American Association for State and Local History that this accomplishment or this program, in comparison with all similar accomplishments and programs in North America, deserves the adjective excellent."
